''Untangling the Web's Languages'' (April 20) is likely to raise false hopes about Everymail.com, a multilingual service that allows users to type messages in dozens of languages. The site is indeed very nice but has some limitations.

First, one must have a Windows PC. And a person with an Everymail account cannot receive ordinary e-mail written in, say, Hebrew if the message was mailed by most of the properly configured e-mail programs that do send Hebrew. The reason is that Everymail is committed to Unicode, which (sparing the readers technical details) is probably the wave of the future for multilingual e-mail but not used very much in e-mail yet. The upshot is that almost all Hebrew e-mail today will not be readable in Everymail.
